This could have been a great anime if not for the fact that the ending was so unsatisfactory. I was enjoying this great romance with an engaging and intriguing story but then it just ended and then, when I looked it up, it had no sequel. So, until this anime gets a second season or some sort of OVA to wrap it up properly, I unfortunately can't give it any rating above 7. For now, I can only say it was good, which is kind of sad considering how greatly I was enjoying it. I really do hope that it gets a second season, orelse I'll be kind of mad. It's so frustrating how the creators do this thing where they stop the anime right in the middle of the story only to tell us: "hey! Go read the manga!"

I guess I must be tsundere towards shoujo in general, rather than plain masochistic. The reason? I tend to dislike the genre because of all those generic heroines, bastard love interests and utterly pointless love triangles among countless other things. Yet because of series like Natsume Yuujinchou or Lovely Complex I keep torturing myself through all that wangst and forced drama. And, admittedly, it's worth it more often than not. Such is the case with Ao Haru Ride.
The premise is nothing out of the common--the two main characters used to like each other during middle school, got separated and then found each other again yearslater. However, they had changed, and not for the better. The female lead, Futaba, has drastically altered her persona in order to be accepted. The male lead, Kou, has become a cold, condescending asshole as a shield against the rest of the world. It's no wonder they initially dislike each other.


Mostly.


Surprisingly, Futaba is quite likeable from the beginning. From what I've read, she's relatable enough for people to root for her from the very beginning. In my case, I mostly relate to Kou, but that's because I relate to asshole male leads in general. Ironically.

Speaking of which, Kou turned out to be intriguing from the beginning as well, mostly because, like Futaba, he does have depth beneath the usual archetype. Kou's sadness is palpable the way Futaba's own loneliness is, which make them all the more real.


Sadly, sans Kou's older brother, the rest of the cast seems fairly dull not because they lack screentime, but because they seem closer to their own archetypes than the main leads. We get the lone wolf, Murao, the girly sweetie-pie, Yuuri, and the overly-energetic dude, Kominato. Their actions and thoughts are too predictable which is disappointing because they do have potential.


If I were to mention the anime's highlight... it would be the art. Those watercolor backgrounds can be plain spectacular at times, and the animation, along with the soundtrack, effectively conveys an atmosphere fitting the story's themes. The art style has to be one of my favorite among shoujo. It's detailed without being over-the-top and very distinctive as well. In fact, I may or may not have initially read the manga because of the art. It would've been among my top 20 had an idiotic character not been introduced halfway just for drama, apparently. But that's another story.


Ao Haru Ride is not groundbreaking, but it's good. It does try to convey a message rather than just mindlessly entertain. The characters do grow and mature, Kou even more so than Futaba herself. There's a fair share of genuinely tender scenes and a couple that really did 'tug at my heartstrings'. I'd consider it above average, but not among the best of the genre. Except for the art. I'm in love with the art. Damn Sugisaka Io.

Plot and Story Line
It's the first time that the MAL community rated an anime exactly as I did. I gave it an 8 (well 7,95 is close). The story is funny, cute, romantic and realistic. I never believed that I would say this one day, but I really enjoyed this romance. I loved it. Now let's get this started...
To the plot.
It's a fantastic story that, as I believe, happened to most of us at least once in a similar way. There is that cute and nice girl in the middle school called Futaba Yoshioka. She is very popular among the guys in her class andthey really like her, but the girls don't. "Jealous girlies". She was alone most of the time, until that one rainy day when she met Kou Tanaka in a shrine where both of them tried to find shelter from the rain. Of curse that event was followed by a couple of other cute and precious memories and they even made plans  for meeting at the Summer Festival. Unfortunately Kou never showed up and literary 

disappeared  afterwards. 

Time passed and Futaba is now a high school student with a complete different attitude and personality. She had enough of being alone all the time and now she gave up her cuteness and femininity so the girls don't become jealous again. Tomboyish  and with a disheveled look she encounters the only guy she ever loved, again. Now with a life turned upside down she tries to find her place where she belongs to. 


With a set plot, let's discuss. The Story Line.  


Where does the strength of Ao Haru Ride lie? In my opinion it is the background story of Kou. As always, Rule No.1. "NO SPOILERS", but I'll tell you this. The whole first season was mainly focused of Futaba trying to reach the old Kou. All the flashbacks that were woven into the present story were amazing. The makers created an intriguing story in the past, that affects the present, which is also a great love story on its own. So you basically get two parallel story lines in the past that meet in the present. I've always loved

 retrospection.   

The second thing that made me love this anime is the diversity of the mini story lines in the show. It doesn't talk about Futaba's and Kou's relationship alone. There are tons of others, for instance my favorite side story line, the relationship between Kou and his older brother Youichi. And there are many more. I just hope that the makers will soon announce a second season, but for now it doesn't look like that. The manga finished airing in February, 2015, so I'll still keep my fingers crossed. 


And now, let's just focus on the main story line. The core, let's say. The romance between Kou and Futaba. I hate the romance genre because it is full of cliches and "I expected that to happen" situations.  But I'll probably give anime romances a chance. Maybe Clanned, but let's talk about that later. Kou and Futaba. It's not just a silly teenage relationship. It goes from that cute kids love to a serious love, and it's so good. There are so many moments where you have to say: "Awwww!". You just have to. It's somehow more realistic and it's not because I am AnimeGirl that caused me love this anime-relationships. They are always so undefined yet clear. They are so cute, and I love cute things. Too bad anime is not real, even love would be much easier. 


As a conclusion, Ao Haru Ride is a fascinating story with an intriguing plot that will keep you on tenterhooks until the last second. There are no plot holes and the story is also smooth without any unnecessary and stupid plot twists. There are always new mini stories that appear, but they slowly make their way into the show. They always appear at the right time to keep you interested till the end. 


Characters

Guys, I could really go on talking about the characters the whole night. They are all so special and interesting in their own way. I give it a 10 for uniqueness. But, as always, here are the main two characters of Ao Haru Ride.


Futaba Yoshioka. You have no idea how much this girl reminds me of my-self. I kinda was in a very similar situation at Middle School too. That's so unbelievable. The only difference is that in middle school I tried to hide my true self, while in high school I did the exact opposite. That's why I was happy when Futaba realized that it's not worth being someone else if there are people who accept you exactly how you are. 


Kou Tanaka or later in the story Kou Mabuchi is the most interesting character in the whole story. I always wanted to know more about him, and luckily the anime reveals his life story, which is believe me or not on e of the best background stories I've ever seen. By the way, I love cats too. He is one of the cool guys acting emotionless while being very sensible and full of emotions on the inside. I love this type of characters because they are always so full of surprises. 


Animation

Well, maybe the story isn't, but the animation definitely is a "As expected" since the makers of Ao Haru Ride are also the makers of the anime "Psycho-Pass" and "Guilty Crown" (Check out both of the reviews on my blog). And I hope you have seen the animation of those two. The word BRILLIANT is not enough to describe the stuff that your eyes see when you watch this. I love it, and since I've always found bad animation extremely repelling I was glad that this story came with the animation and style it deserves. 

The idea that I liked the most in Ao Haru Ride is the way they put that watercolor effect in the flashback scenes. Awesome!


Conclusion

If you want to change my opinion about something you really have to have good arguments to convince me. Ao Haru Ride for example really convinced me that romance anime are not bad at all. I loved it. Animation, Story, Plot, Characters. Everything is in its right place. I would really give it a try if you haven't already watched it. 


MORE REVIEWS: worldofanimegirl.blogspot.com

Ao Haru Ride gives off a a powerful vibe of excitement that makes you crave for more. While watching this series and waiting every week for a new episode i experience that vibe 80% of the time. As their are some flaws to this series.
Story 10/10 - The story focuses around Yoshioka Futaba's life, an outrageously pretty girl, which is a problem. This problem makes her decide to change her image as a person and her life choices. All before she reunites with an old middle school friend that let me just say, had an impact on her life then and rapidly picks up now.Throughout the series she tries to connect with him emotionally, to understand him. This story may seem like your typical anime love story, and unfortunately it is. But it's with a hint of , " I wasn't expecting that" , and little things that makes this anime unique. It paces quickly but that's a good thing about it. The episodes pick up where they left off, kind of like a continuous movie. 


Art 8/10- As i never really focus on artwork in anime. This one was eh. It had some nice effects that would catch an eye. All though the artwork does look lazy , like there are things that are missing/ could be improved. But the over all art work was as plain as day.


Sound 9/10- The voice actors fit well with the character's personality. The OP (opening) is very catchy. The tracks throughout the series all though were barely noticeable, as in ,could have been better especially the ending. But the overall sound made a feel at ease and makes you not worried about a character with an annoying voice to come along.


Character 9/10- These characters are your classic , cheesy,  romance anime characters when it comes down to the personality. But their reaction to certain situations sure caught me off guard. The supporting cast is very important to the story which gives a relaxed feeling since not everything revolves around the main characters. Every character has something of their own. There are some characters to come across in dislike though, but i found that to be the creator's intentions. These characters aren't all unique, their are some flaws in them but that's what makes it even more interesting, to find out what they'll do next.


Enjoyment 10/10- Did i mention every week i couldn't wait for a new episode? Every episode seemed to go by so fast because of the enjoyment i had for it. Theirs moments where you laugh uncontrollably , gasp in awe , and feel embarrassed for the characters like your in the anime yourself. I definitely will remember this series for a long time, and may possibly watch it again. It made me feel so much excitement, it was addicting. All though i don't like how short the series is ( 12 episodes), I feel that there's a huge cliff hanger at the end which puts me unease. 


Overall 10/10

One of the problems in the anime industry is that there aren't enought shoujo manga adapations. Another problem is that when those adaptations happen, they are often made incredibly generic. 
Ao Haru Ride aired during summer 2014 and was composed by 12 episodes + an OAV produced by production I.G. 
STORY: 7/10
The story starts in a really interesting way. The two main characters, Kou and Futaba (who liked each other in the past), haven't seen each other in years and when they meet again they're incredibly changed. Kou is not the gentle, femmine boy anymore (he's a douche) and Futaba is trying to change herpersonality to fit in. Will Futaba find out about what happend to Kou? What made him change so much? Will she be able to break throught? And most important, will they be able to act like themselves?

The anime covers the first part of the manga, which is still ongoing, so it obviously ends with an open ending. Even thought the last episodes actually closes the circle that started in the first ep, and it gives a feeling of conclusion.

25 minutes episodes feel like they're 3 minutes long.

While the pacing is good, the main problem about the story is that the writers changed too much the original atmosphere in the manga. Futaba's inner monologues and struggles, that are on of the best part in the manga, result almost swallow and boring. The drama didn't have enought impact and Kou is almost made emotionless. I blame that on the


ART: 5/10

I may say, the art sometimes looks beautiful, like actually amazing. The backgrounds are fantastic and the colors and palettes are artistic.

But. There's something i can't forgive, the animations. They are so bad they kill the mood of the story, in a dramatic anime YOU NEED good animations to convey the feelings of the characters. I almost laught when i was supposed to cry cause they were so bad, especially since the manga art is so beautiful. 


SOUND: 8/10

While the soundtrack is really nice, and the tracks are memorable, there's an abuse of the track "i will" by chelsy, which really gets old after some time. I get it. You love that song. But you can't have 23567 scenes that are supposed to convey different emotions with the same bg track.


CHARACTER: 8/10

This is a characters driven show. Every single persone of the group has something that makes them different and real. They have flaws and they make mistakes and you somehow can really feel them. You know that are real, even if they aren't. You keep rooting for Futaba like she's your sister, you want her to succed. And the great thing is that Kou actually has motivations for his change. It's believable. Their love is believable. At the end of the show you're left wanting more. You want to know what happens next.


ENJOYMENT: 10/10

Seriously. The show has lots of mistakes, it becomes a generico shoujo after the first episodes. But oh my god i wish it had 100 more episodes. From a subjective point of view, this thing really touches your soul. I suggest everyone to keep going with the manga because the best is yet to come.


OVERALL: 7/10

Watch this for a nice shoujo anime. Read the manga for an epic emotional rollercoaster (10/10)

Ao Haru Ride .. a typical love story that can make you ... HOOKED. I don´t even know why but this anime was really easy to watch..  
A resume about my experience with this anime: 
1st episode: Ok .. 
3rd episode: This is actually nice, i liked those intense moments 
6th episode: Well .. kinda clichê but at least is fun to watch 
9th episode: What a surprise .. i wasn´t expecting such a nice feeling from this show ... 
12th episode + OVA (13th episode) : I wanted more .. even though the end is fine. 
Story: 6/10. Maybe the worst point here.It has so many things that simply doesn´t make any sense. Why Why Why Why .. i was always questioning myself about this anime .. 


The story is not original at all, the setup is not that great as well. The main male character has some dark past .. (this was supposed to be a mystery but as soon as they said in the anime that he had troubles with his life i realized immediately what was the problem .. and i was right). 


This anime sticks too much with clichê themes and i didn´t liked it. Anyway the story isn´t awful. 


Art: 8/10. Really interesting art. Well drawn characters and vibrant backgrounds makes the up the mood for the intense moments in the anime. There are tiny problems in terms of detail and depth in the background and in the characters but overall it looks great. 


Sound: 9/10. Please .. the sound is ... normal for the most part .. weak opening, reasonable ending .. BUT. Well this anime has one of my favourite tracks of all time. It is one of those tracks that you can use everywhere that will make the scene better. Really impressive, i just loved it. I watched this anime 2 months ago and i still hear that track every once in a while only to remember the feeling. 


Character: 7/10. So as the story, the characters are pretty much clichê characters. Even though not having nothing new to show, the couple here is really cute and fun to watch so i think they deserve a chance. Nice reactions, nice dialogues, everything is well done. 


Enjoyment: 8/10. As i said, this anime is really easy to watch. If you are a big fan of romance I think you will have a good time with this show. Being small only helps. It makes the faster in terms of pace so we don´t get bored (unlike other romance anime where we have entire episodes dedicated to comedy or exploring any other character that isn´t relevant, here on Ao Haru Ride they only spend time developing the main characters and their relation.)


Overall: 7/10. This anime worth it's time so I think if you like romance, maybe you should give it a try. If you are not a big fan of romances, then you can leave this one. You won´t be loosing anything important by not watching this anime. Like I said, it is pretty normal.

After giving a lot of thought, I finally decided to write a review about this anime.Before I begin, do note that this review is only regarding the anime and not the manga ( which is still running as of today)
Story : 7/10
The main girl, Yoshioka Futaba, a middle-schooler is depicted as the typical young shoujo school girl.She’s cute, pretty and attracts all the boys with her looks and personality.As a result of this, she isn't very popular amongst the girls and barely has any friends. That is, until she comes across Kou Tanaka. a soft-spoken, gentle guy with whom she gradually develops a friendship. However,after a misunderstanding, their relationship as friends ends when he transfers schools over summer vacation. In high school, her world is turned around once again when she meets Kou again, this time under the name of Kou Mabuchi.  \n
Fast forward 3 years.\n
Futaba is now no longer feminine and she acts like a complete slob just so that her so called ‘friends’ don’t leave her and hate her because she doesn’t attract guys anymore. However, he’s changed too, he’s no longer ‘nice’ or ‘gentle’ and he’s actually quite silent and mean now. So life carries on after that … do they still have feelings for each other, do they even remember each other?\n
The story is a simple one that is relatable and yet offers a lot of intrigue and suspense.\n
Art: 8/10\n
The animation is amazing and Production I.G has done a great job in keeping the original look of the manga, something I haven't seen in other shows lately.\n
Although the show billed as a shoujo romantic comedy ,it’s a pretty basic light coming-of-age in high school tale.\n
Sound: 9/10\n
The sound is amazing, with a medley of heart-warming and and beautiful songs that would definitely strike a chord.\n
Character: 6/10\n
Character development is one area I hope that this anime had focused more upon. Apart from the two main characters, not much focus is given on the supporting characters which would have added to more depth and enjoyment in the story.At times, it is one-dimensional and could have been improved a lot.\n
Enjoyment: 7/10\n
Futaba fits the bill perfectly as an awkward lead as she fumbles through her attempts to get closer to Kou and giving us a lot to enjoy as we listen to her thoughts. The anime manages to seamlessly integrate both romance and humour, providing for a fun-filled watch.\n
Overall: 7.5/10\n
It is one of those shows that start off strong, but unnecessary filler through the mid-episodes can be a bother.\n
 Still, Ao Haru Ride breaks beyond the cliches of typical shoujo anime and a master of subtlety, realism, and pacing, not to mention its brilliant use of art style and understanding of human relationships. \n
In conclusion:\n
If you want to watch a romance anime, watch this show.\n

When I found this anime I didn't know that I was going to like it as much as I did. I really like romance anime/manga but I didn't think that this one would be ranked as high as it was. I was blown away! The manga had me clinging to every word, just waiting for the next chapter. I'm so excited for chapter 46 to come outthat I can barely sit still anymore. This anime was pretty good in my opinion. Its strong points were the romance and the few comedic parts it had. It had really good animation and the story was another big selling point of this anime. Some of its weaknesses in my opinion, like most romance anime involving more than one character liking the same guy. No couple really is formed, but you can probably assume from the way the anime ends, but there's no satisfaction in actually seeing a relationship established. 
This is why I think this anime was worthy of an 8. Main reason being i LOVED the main male character, hemight've seemed a bit cold, but I think his personality was pretty cool. I liked how much all the characters, not just a few, all of the characters evolved throughout the anime. Another big reason i liked this anime was because it reminded me a lot of Tonari no Kaibutsu-kun. A few of the characters looked identical and their personalities were very similar.\n\n
Overall, this is an anime you should check out, definitely worth a go.

I just have to start off to say this anime is fairly mediocre.  It could have been I started watching it with too high of expectations but I don't think that was the issue.
Over the course of the twelve episodes there is very little plot or development.  The two main characters knew each other from middle school and had mutually liked one another only for Kou (the boy) to suddenly move away after Futaba (the girl) caused an awkward scene after he asked her to go to a festival with him.
When Kou returns and Futaba see him she is attached to the pastversion of Kou she knew and tried to apply it to the Kou that had been away from her for 3 years.  The whole anime is about these two and a "developing romance" but honestly it was entirely one-sided for about 90% of the series.\n\n
Kou's hidden niceness makes it appear as though he has affections early on but Futaba's character explains it best when she states that he is just nice though he tries to act as though he doesn't care because he is scared.\n\n
If you are looking for a romance anime that has no real romantic closure at the end this would be an anime to watch.  I can only hope there is a 2nd season in the works otherwise this is a very boring anime.

If you're the type of person who loves sweet romances, this is the anime for you.
The manga and the anime comparison:
 Ao haru ride is one of the best romance manga i have read. I would say the anime didn't do much justice, as most scenes had to be cut to fit into the anime, so the ending had to be changed as well. However, the anime still managed to show the loving connection between the lovers and managed to keep the audience entertain with their relationship. As well as including the important scenes which makes us go like "why can't I have a relationshiplike that too?". So I would say the anime is still pretty good!\n\n
The Art and Songs:\n
I love the way each characters are drawn, as it portrayed the characters' personality well. For example, the guy ( (Kou Mabuchi) had a very charming face to show how charming of a person he is as well as the girl (Futaba Yoshioka) having a very kawaii look giving her a friendly aura. The background may not be as spectacular like Spirited away or Your Name, but it still gives a heartwarming effect. As for the song, it was sweet and upbeat which perfectly displayed how the anime was.\n\n
In conclusion, I enjoyed it and would highly recommend this to anyone who loves romance animes :)

Story: 7
The story plot is a very typical shoujo anime plot with a cool male lead and a sweet female lead. The reason why I enjoyed this anime so much is because it's more realistic. The characters don't fall in love with each other instantly like all those other cliche romance stories. Of course they fall in love at the end because it's a shoujo romance anime, but the journey through their relationship is very unique. I'm actually not a big fan of romance shows because of how misleading and fake the relationships are. That's why I enjoyed Ao Haru Ride.
Art: 8
The art is verybeautiful. Each character has a unique look that matches their personality. It has a 3D feel to it and the animations are not flat.\n\n
Sound: 7\n
I love the sound tracks in this anime. The voices in the subs are really good too. They fit the characters perfectly and the audio is great. Good music, good sounds and good voicing.\n\n
Character: 8\n
I absolutely love every character in Ao Haru Ride. They're all really cliche but unique at the same time. Futaba is the usual cheerful shoujo anime girl. She is hardworking and wants to be someone that everyone likes. Kou is the usual cool and silent type. These characteristics are very popular amongst shoujo animes but the reason why Ao haru Ride is so special is because the characters stay true to themselves. They don't lose their personalities but they develop themselves like real people would. They also do it in a realistic way.\n\n
Enjoyment: 8\n
There are many scenes in Ao Haru Ride that I love re watching over and over again. Many cute romantic scenes that'll make you feel warm and fuzzy on the inside. There's comedy, romance and romance scenes that will touch your heart.

I truly enjoyed this--- to the point where I felt compelled enough to write a review. 
It's rare to find a show that is so mature for being set in high school. I was so refreshed by the absence of all the endless miscommunication and misunderstandings that seem to be a pattern in these Slice of Life/Shoujo types. 
Don't get me wrong, being a teen is awkward no doubt, but when it gets to the point where the characters are constantly confused by each other's actions and issues get drawn out over 5-6 episodes (sometimes the whole season)--- it can get a little tedious. 
Thedialogue is so natural and the chemistry between everyone flows together perfectly. \n\n
I will 100% be reading the manga to continue the story and will always be in hopes for another season to pop up down the line. \n\n

Ao Haru Ride is a Shoujo something out of the ordinary that fulfilled my expectations (which were not very high) with a simple story achieves its goal of transmitting the feelings and melancholy of the characters making you have a good time.
The story is fine, it shows Futaba and Kou who meet again after a couple of years in which they had to repress their feelings towards the other by a set of problems. What I did not like was that the story becomes very slow over the last few chapters and the ending is unfinished and to some extent disappointing.
The art has something goodand bad, what I liked were the animations type "watercolor" in the retrospective and scenes of the Secondary. What I did not like was the disproportionate form of the facial expressions of the characters.


The Soundtrack (in my opinion) is the strong point of the anime, Opening is one of those who is happy to hear at the beginning of each chapter and the Ending is quite calmer but just as good. I also really liked the song "I Will" by Chelsy, which sounds in certain scenes during the story, which will go directly to my Playlist.


The characters also have opposite scores, the melancholy girl Futaba and the Inexpressive Kou are the main protagonists who cover almost 95% of the story, they are not memorable characters but they manage to entertain for a good time. Of the secondary characters who has more participation is Yuuri who also develops feelings towards Kou, the rest of personages hardly appears forcibly in some scenes.


In conclusion Ao Haru Ride is an average story that will make you have a good time if you are of those who like the Slice of Life, I really liked it.

To be honest, I can recognize that Ao Haru Ride is pretty cheesy and extremely cliche. However, it is my guilty pleasure.
I was very unsure of this anime during the first episode because the main female character has an annoying voice and the main male was kind of lame, but he definitely changes into a much better character! (Can't say the same for her annoying voice).
The storyline isn't original and definitely not surprising. The way the main characters argue and how they always just "happen" to run into each other is pretty ridiculous. 
I think if I didn't like the main male character so much,I wouldn't have watched this show, but he definitely made the show entertaining.\n\n
I probably wouldn't recommend this show to most people, but for those looking for a corny romantic time-killer, this is the show for you! Not sure if they're renewing for another season, but if you want to know the ending, you'll have to follow up the last episode with the manga.

"Ao Haru Ride" is one hell of an emotional journey.
 "Ao Haru Ride," a heartwarming romance piece, is a story that captures the heart with its beautiful art and intricate plot design.
In this lovely piece of art, Futaba is played by Uchida, Maaya (the voice of Takanashi, Rikka [Chuunibyou demo Koi ga Shitai!], Iki, Hiyori [Noragami], and Alluka Zoldyck [HunterxHunter]). Uchida undergoes a marvelous transformation, suddenly becoming a jaded young lady with a weakness for love. Her portrayal of Futaba is wonderful in that she's not annoying with Futaba's needy mannerisms. Another gem of the voice acting world is Kaji, Yuki (voice of Finnian [BlackButler], Alibaba Saluja [Magi], and Eren Jeager [Attack on Titan]) staring as the voice of Mabuchi, Kou. This is literally the dark side of Kaji's voice, and I say sexy! Kaji continues to hit his target dead on by bringing the insecure and shut off Kou to life.


The most wonderful part about the anime is the character development. There are massive amounts of character development going on! And Sakisaka, Io, the author of the story, hits her audience with the most heartbreaking stories. Also, not to mention the art is just lovely. There are some many details put into the art from the characters to the backgrounds. The style alone just makes one feel like they're floating through a sea of beauty. The only sad part about "Ao Haru Ride" is that the concept is used quite often -- but it is still a worthwhile anime to watch.


Those who take pleasure in giggling at the budding romance of two characters will be sure to love this anime. There are many characters a viewer can connect with, and no one has to be limited to the main two. However, to the people who are jaded and think love cannot possibly exist (like me), you will simply wonder why all these characters behave like they do. This anime will simply not be an enjoyment. But regardless of one's personal feelings, this anime is a sweet, innocent romance that can give the feeling of hope to all who watch it.

-

Story - 8

"Ao Haru Ride" has a delicate storyline that will capture one's interest immediately. Unfortunately, this type of romance has been explored many times. However, that does not mean that this isn't worth the while. It certainly is. "Ao Haru Ride" is like take a breath of fresh spring air.


Art - 9

The artwork is beautiful and so detailed from character design to backgrounds. Sakisaka, Io has a lovely style that conveys the message of sweet innocence. I can tell a lot of passion and hard work went into the art for this anime.


Music - 8

The music perfectly fit the mood of this piece. The opening was filled with cute curiosity with its bubbly, yet melodic tune. Ending the anime is a lovely piece that is relaxing, and makes everything feel right. The music inside the anime were also lovely pieces that were perfectly timed with the action.


Character - 9

There was a lot of character development. I got to see Futaba mature even though her childish qualities remained. I also got to see many sides of Kou that seemed unlikely to be in him, but they were and it made me happy. Even the side characters like Yuuri, a cute girl who was ostracized by the females like Futaba, and Murao, a mature girl who has a crush on a teacher, grew in unexpected ways.


Enjoyment - 8

I normally don't enjoy romances, but "Ao Haru Ride" really captured my attention. It was high on my hype list, and earned an ever higher spot as I was watching it. There were some point where I avoided having to watch this anime, but that was only because of the cliffhangers left by the previous episode.


Overall - 8.4

"Ao Haru Ride" was a great anime, and I'm glad I invested my time into it. Staring at the artwork and listening to the music were great treats for my senses. I even sang along to the opening song. But watching the character develop was really was the best part of this anime. It's a really good show for one that's been done so many times, and I really loved it.

Ao Haru Ride - A Shoujo done correctly
Blue Spring Ride is a series of shoujo manga/anime written and illustrated by Io Sakisaka.
(Which by the way is a woman that makes sense for this story be at the maximum level of friend zone)
It began to be serialized in February 2011 in the journal "Bessatsu Margaret" of Shueisha.
The anime version was made by Production I.G. and directed by Ai Yoshimura aired in Japan in July 2014.
The opening theme of the series is "Sekai wa Koi ni Ochiteiru" by Chico and HoneyWorks while the ending theme is "Buru" by Fujifabric.
It was also made a live action directed byTakahiro Miki film was released on December 13, 2014.\n
The genders in this story are Comedy, Drama, Romance, School, Shoujo and Slice of Life.\n
The first tankōbon volume was released on April 13, 2011, and ten volumes have been released until May 23, 2014.\n\n
Synopsis: Futaba Yoshioka liked to give a new direction to his life.Yoshioka had no friends because many boys liked her. However, the one for whom she was in love, Kou Tanaka, pulled away from her before she could confess. Now in the secondary, Yoshioka is determined to be unkind and rude to the guys, so that her new friends do not feel jealous of her. She was happy with her life, to reconnect with Kou, who now uses the name Kou Mabuchi. He says he was in love with her at the time, but nowadays he says that their feelings are indifferent.\n
This anime has only one available season (12 episodes) and one Ova serving episode 13.\n\n
Review: For this review, it will be like "You know when / mistress put a wall forward and are waiting for someone who really cares to chop it?"\n
This anime is the true definition of that phrase. As a story, however, is something "harping on." The chick likes him and tries everything he just says "I love you" then the end comes the part of friend zone or simply he did not like it that way. This is something repetitive and delays a possible new existing Shoujo anime style. The animation is cheerful, energetic and brilliant - mix a lot of colors that combine well with their own characters and the very atmosphere of the anime, not to say that the background music complements the series a fantastic way - serves as reinforcement to give suspense current or so scenes to give a sense of emotions present for a moment in silence.\n
Personal advice: - Sometimes seeing Shoujo anime help us to understand certain things that we do not understand especially if we like someone that much.\n
I advise undoubtedly this anime shoujo, even for those who do not like anime where the characters date at the end or something.

I really, really, really did not enjoy this anime. It was a recommendation from Black Prince and the Wolf Girl so I came into full of hope. For the first half, I was prepared to review this positively. There are definitely similarities to both Black Prince and to My Little Monster and the variations on the characters were good. 
I started getting frustrated by how similarly all of the characters appeared. The animation level is quite high so it made it feel all the worse when we meet a few characters and it's hard to find the difference between them and the existing characters (ex.leadership training, middle school classmates/friends).


In episode 7 or 8, something small happens that led to my complete loss of enjoyment for the rest of the show. For the remaining episodes, I kept waiting for that element to be picked up but it either wasn't or it was done so in a cruel fashion. I shouldn't have to guess either way.


I understand the manga goes further so it's entirely possible that this show fully planned on a second season. I want my anime to be able to stand alone though. I want the show to entice me to go read by making me care about the characters and plot lines and want the extra detail. Here it felt more like a lot of loose plot threads. It's the anime version of ending your book with a cliffhanger to force your hand in buying the sequel. It leaves a sour taste in your mouth.


Kou and Futaba are nicely designed though. I really liked the spin that she was more of a tomboy and wanted to beat against the expectations of her femininity while still being a fully functioning student. Kou started out well and especially the flashbacks of how he used to be juxtaposed with how he is now were great. He ended up wearing on me.


In the end, I personally wish I hadn't watched this. It feels a lot like Black Prince and the Wolf Girl, My Little Monster, and Orange all smushed into one but without being as good as any of them. I don't recommend.

The story revolves around a girl named Futaba, a recluse whom was unpopular in middle school because she was popular with the boys. The jealousy which emanated from the other girls in her class made her an outcast; it didn’t help that because of this she developed a hatred of boys which compounded her already lonely existence. That is until she meets Kou, a mysteriously sweet boy and classmate at a local shrine. There the pair bond and quickly develop a friendship before outside influences conspire against the pair and Kou ends up leaving the school shortly after the summer break ends. Three years later,Futaba is a different person from the middle school girl she once was; she puts on a persona in order to be popular, unattractive to boys and not be a social misfit and it shows. For her, life is good and stable…until Kou comes back under a different name. He too is a different person and the pair are aware of this. They have the past, but that’s all it is now. Who are they? In any case, they don’t give up and over time they both start to get to know one another and Futaba especially re-evaluates her life choices and starts to change back into the girl that she used to be using traditional shoujo romance tropes along the way.

Okay, I'll try to be as concise as possible:
Story: 8. 
This is a story of love between a lonely boy and a happy-go-lucky girl (who used to be really shy and calm) after not having seen each other for years. They obviously have changed and it is like a "second opportunity" story. Even though it is mostly like "the typical shojo anime" one strong point is that it doesn't focus only in the main story (the one of the leading characters) but also in the stories of the supporting characters. 
A negative point of this anime is that the most exciting events aren't shown, asthey will happen later... but it is a good start and indeed a nice tv adaptation, pretty loyal to the manga.


Art: 8.


Shojo-like art, with decent character design, backgrounds and all that. I didn't like some of the colours chosen (for example Touma's hair or even Futaba's. Her hair is okay, but I would have expected a lighter brown.). Facial expressions are probably the best of the art, they are really funny.


Sound: 8.


The OP is really appropiate, the lyrics absolutely fit the anime's story. The rest of the OST is nice too.


Characters: 9


I really like how every single character has an unique and pretty complex personality. They aren't exactly stereotypical characters and they are far from being perfect. In addition, they start to become more mature little by little, changing constantly and accepting their reality... without forgetting what they want to achieve. Moreover, they make a nice friends gang.


Enjoyment: 9


I have enjoyed this show soooo much that I continued reading online the manga, even if I really hate reading online. Right now, I'm even buying the manga because it has been licensed in my country. This is a story that has never bored me, specially because I strongly identify myself with Futaba. I hope another season of the anime is produced because the best is about to come!


Overall: 9. Nice anime but still can improve.

Ao Haru Ride is exactly what a seinin-classified viewer who is tired of slice of life harems is looking for in a shoujo series. The show focuses on the cute, albeit slowly developing, relationship between two high school students, who once harbored crushes on each other. It has some nice, romantic development similar to what you'd find in Tonari no Kaibutsu-kun or Sukitte Ii na yo with a bit of group-based development more recently found in P.A. Works shows like Glasslip or Nagi no Asukara. It's nice to hear a story told from a girl's point of view for once, especially in a setting thatdoesn't involve swarms of overly-bishounen dudes, pink colors, and sparkles all over the place. If you're sore after watching Glasslip and want an idea of what it could have been, definitely get on this ride.


Animation:

While Production I.G did a pretty good job with the animation overall, it still doesn't match up to P.A. Works in this department. Many episodes (especially the first) start out with a flashback. This utilizes a noticeably blurry, painted/drawn style with very little color saturation. Note that this is an artistic touch and the majority of the show isn't in this style (for better or worse- the former in my opinion). The non-flashback scenes use a more-saturated color palette and crisper lines. While the backgrounds are a bit less detailed than some other shows, they still serve their purpose. Character animation is fairly good overall with distinguishable characters and a good focus on facial animations; expect a good quantity of crying and other cute/awkward/embarrassing moments. Eyes are a bit on the large side but not really a distraction once you get used to it. It might just be the hairstyle but Yuuri reminds me a lot of Sayaka from Bokura wa Minna Kawaisou. Oh, yes there are manly tears as well.


This is definitely not an action show and equally not an ecchi show. There is probably one accident involving Futaba but it's sort of a reverse-ecchi moment, it will make sense when you see it. In any case, emotions and facial reads are definitely more in girls' domain, and it definitely shows here.


Sound:

The show starts with a light pop song that fits with the relatively light, somewhat mellow pacing of the show. The OP tune is fair in general but the main theme does get a bit catchy after awhile. I don't normally like slow guy songs, but the ED is among the better ones. I also liked how they timed the animation of the stars with the initial piano notes. I will give this show a huge prop for using a nice insert song and tying it as a series theme into the BGM. This central theme alone elevates the BGM above average shows for me.


Veteran Maaya Uchida leads a veteran cast including the likes of Ai Kayano, Marina Inoue, and even Aya Hisakawa. Daisuke Hirakawa, on the mens side, gets the thumbs up for the optimistic dual onii-chan and sensei role. A lot of the show is dialogue driven and the VAs do a great job of bringing out their respective personalities.


Story:

Our protagonist Futaba once had a crush for a soft-spoken, short guy named Kou Tanaka. Unfortunately for her, he mysteriously vanished from her life. Fast forward to high school and Futaba finally meets up with him again. How will she take advantage of this rare, gem opportunity? Unfortunately, she's going to have to work for it as people apparently change as they grow.


This show really bridges a lot of categories in a nice way. It effectively balances elements of slice of life, romance, comedy, and drama and all the while manages to fend off girly vibes. It is a pretty slow show in terms of the overarching plot, but perhaps that is for the better as a more realistic portrayal of relationships (cue the instant girlfriend). As a bonus, there are subplots and themes tied into the main story that are well developed and explored. Not only does Futaba have to figure out Kou, she also has to deal with her self-image and the fickle topic of friendship. In summary, you're definitely going to get your share of development in this show.


As for the structure of the story, it pretty much follows a single, linear plot with a slight focus on Futaba for the first half and a slight focus on Kou in the second half. A lot of the events are a bit on the predictable side but there are definitely some surprises hidden in the show. The story grows to a small bump of a climax near the end and spends an entire episode on the conclusion, a bit unusual but actually quite nice as it gives plenty of resolution.


Character:

Continuing on my rant, I feel as if many shoujo shows carry a more realistic portrayal of people than their shounen (and even seinin) counterparts. Girls worry more about just the dude they're chasing and guys actually are complicated creatures too, not just nice guys who lack bark and bite or overly egotistic, single-minded shouting creatures set on conquering the world. This show does a great job of illustrating these points through character development and interactions in even guy-digestible package. Don't expect any of the finger-waving, highly metaphorical development of Glasslip. In addition to the complexity of the protagonists and their romantic development, I also liked the balance between their development and that of the supporting cast.


Value:

If you haven't yet noticed, I think there's a lot to like about this show. It's not quite as heart-grabbing or dramatic as Golden Time but yet manages to still capture one's attention in a way that makes time fly. It also is one of those shows that leave you with a positive message and overall feeling. Ao Haru Ride is a very entertaining and worthwhile watch for anyone looking for a bit of romance, and a bit of patience for actually getting there.

And here I go again, talking bad and complaining about an anime that eeeeveryone seems to love... But please don't misunderstand me. It's not like I hate Aoharaido. I just feel like... A sadness bomb just exploded in my room. And spread shit everywhere.
Let's talk why.
Ao Haru Ride is one of those shoujo romance of a sweet, smiling an persistent girl triyng to win the love of a cold and strange but handsome guy. The story it's pretty much this and it's the most used cliché in shoujo, by the way.
Now, why is this so bad? Where is the "shit" I've talked before? ~Ohh, comeon, where's your sense of romance?- you may ask. Yeah, I admit, it seems pretty normal, right? But I took a little longer to see why Ao Haru Ride left me with the uneasy feeling that something was wrong hiding between the lines. And by that "wrong" I mean almost all the problems I have with shoujo romances and the reason why I came to like much more of josei mangas. Like, a LOT more. I still struggle to read some manga and see some shoujo anime, but some make me sick and this is one of them. Especially because is one of those stories that when you think of the protagonists, your feelings are always on the threshold between pure anger and shame.


I think shoujo always tends to have some little flaws here and there but most of them I just... Let go. But, since recently many mangas with similar subjects that are not very positive for the readers are showing up and being all popular, especially considering that most of shoujo audience are teenage girls (and grown men, hahaha!), I wanted to at least give some nudges from time to time whenever I find some that are


SO

WRONG

IN

SO

MANY

LEVELS


that kicks you on the balls.


Before starting to explain it, let me just tell you that If you haven't seen all the episodes, please take care because this review may have some minor spoilers, but I'll try my best not to do it, though. And also I will not talk about the whole story, just about two points that scared me enough to see it through totally different eyes.


-------------------------------------------------------


1 - So, let's begin with the episode that shows us the flashback from Kou and his story with his ill mother. 


First, we can clearly see here the prototypical of an asian kid focusing too much on his studies and, even though he regrets it later, because he chose to not spend time with his dying mother. And after, a boy who have to deal with a divorce and start battling with loneliness and his low self-esteem. Kou starts to get distant from his own brother, feeling guilty for not being able to fulfill his promise to him.


I think that's a harsh life and a lot to a young kid to bear, right? Of course, the answer is yes. But seriously, all that was a sadness bomb to me and I'm not the first one to say it that way. And like the first person I've saw talking about this, we are on 21st century and we really should start taking mental illness seriously by stop dropping romance bullshit on it. And of course, this is not happening on Aoharaido. Futaba keeps idly trying to form a relationship with whats essentially an ill person. A lot of fan-girls disagreed, of course, but if you make a list of all Kou's reactions at the anime to everything and show it to a professional psychologist, you can be sure that the answer will be that he IS rather ill. People who disagree or think it's an overreaction are also part of the problem, and that's my point here. People need to stop thinking that depression is not a serious illness like any other, because IT IS and it kills as much as any other disease does. So, instead of making a character like Kou to fight the stigma surrounding depression and other mental health related illnesses, we see a boy in a clear stage of depression being forced to maintain a relationship of friendship and to endure a loving relationship he most likely has no emotional condition to deal with. Then, my most hated cliché is used: "Love heals everything". And I really don't know where a forced relationship with someone who needs psychological treatment can be "healing" somehow. So, I really need you guys to understand one thing: If you realize that depression is a disease, are you or are you not sick? Yes, of course you’re sick! You need help! And, above all, the last thing you should worry about is your love life.


Ao Haru Ride is a story that should have tooked a different direction and... Gosh, it would have been an excellent anime if it were one of the few that help deconstructing the stigma around this issue. Futaba had to accept the fact that there wasn't anything she could do but to be supportive and friendly. Then, maybe later, when he’s healthy again, they can even consider love. But instead, the story’s trapped in the constraints of a stereotypical shoujo anime. His friends just tell him "ganbatte" with their actions all the time and take him anywhere, like it would solve everything. Good intentions, yes. But no mental illness can be cured with that. And again, please, this illness need to be taken seriously.


The point here is just to tell you guys that Ao Haru Ride was really frustrating to watch. And I'm not the first person to also say that just hanging around with friends will not cure a sick person like Kou and a girl like Futaba saying he should just "get over it" won't do the trick too. I see many people cursing Kou and saying that he is a dick, that he is an annoying teenager but no one seems to understand why is he like that. Let's stop and think about it. Should we really say that a boy who have lost his mother and went through so many difficult moments during his youth is just a "damn dick"? What if he came to hate himself so much that cannot even think he deserves to have friends? 


I hope that, although this had been repetitive, helped you to think better about it.


2 - Then we arrived at the scene where Kou bravely "warns" Futaba she should not go around walking with men so confidently. She doubted it, saying she knew he was not like that, and then, in a full glitter scenario, he threatens to rape her.


PLEASE, if you are a woman and a guy that you like needs to pretend that he's going to rape you so you can know that you should not rely on men, make a HUGE favor to yourself and dump him! D-U-M-P H-I-S A-S-S! Forget his existence! Stay far away. This is really serious business, man! And the problem is not only that he threatened to rape her, but also that the scene was embellished, as if this was an exciting or romantic thing. She starts to cry, but not because he threatened her, but for futile reasons still correlated with their attempt to reach the feelings of a person who is not in his best moments of sanity. And fuck! It makes me mad as hell. Is she out of her fucking mind? She should reconsider the priorities of what really looks like a problem! And finally, somebody needs to tell mangakas to STOP romanticizing rape scenes! They need to know that this is nothing but disgusting and outrageous and that guys like that need a doctor, not a fucking stereotyped shoujo anime. They need to think about what they are teaching to teenage girls! Because no one have to accept a relationship like that NEVER!


-------------------------------------------------------


So, in short, we have here a "beautiful" story that trivializes a serious illness and that romanticize rape. Not bad, huh? NO! Gosh... This is fucked up! After a manga as incredible as Strobe Edge, WHY THIS? WHY?


All I wanted to say is that there is nothing more courageous than beeing yourself and realizing that your depression is no cause for shame. And that friends are not crutches, and loves are not magic medicines. If you feel depressed, get help. If your love interest is depressed, encourage him/her to seek help. After all, love is really the same as that silly phrase that says "if you have to force it, it is because it will become shit". Nothing but that.


Maybe I'm just being a boring chitchatter girl, for a change. Maybe I should really move once and for all to josei and stop complaining about shoujo. But since it's still one of my favorite styles of manga, I want at least to keep my critical position! I do it always with all the mangas I read, mainly shoujo. And I always like to say to everyone to do the same, because I think it's healthy and it's something that should be encouraged. For girls who like it and also collect shoujo mangas like me, I just ask you to always keep your eyes open. Because even if the story is all cute and cuddly she is not exempt from criticism. And just because the characters are catching and seemingly true that they are free from flaws and big failures. Mangas and animes are seen as very pure entertainment, but it has always been an influence for a large list of things and it's synonymous of serious work that can cost millions, and it is MEDIA. And by being media, means that they also can sin just trying to reach a bigger audience.


So, sadly, I can't recommend it to anyone that enjoys a healthy love story and a healthy life.

Ao Haru Ride is your typical high school romance, which can be both a good and a bad thing.
The story is nothing new, a girl who wants to change her attitude to become more likeable has someone from the past who stirs her plans up, in this case the main romantic interest. I do quite enjoy stories like this but don't expect anything groundbreaking.
The art is good, it truly fits the show, then again, it's not outstanding. The sound however is something I didn't quite enjoy, all of the tracks felt like they belonged only in the background, instead of stirring up your emotions everyonce in a while, which is needed in an anime like this. \n\n
The characters are alright, but they are again, not groundbreaking. Your typical somewhat 'manly' girl who wants to act more girly and the 'I don't care about anything and don't really show emotions' boy. \n\n
As such, you can probably see the repeating pattern in this review, this anime is not bad, nor is it really amazing. It's a lovely little story, which is certainly enjoyable. The only thing is that nothing really stands out, therefore making the show quite forgetful. If you enjoy romance anime; you would like this one, if you are here for something special; you might want to give it a pass.

it is an exciting anime that makes one think of the girls who are in love what to do I am sorry that there is no second season of this anime but I wish there were, can not leave an open end or not?
I like the characters as they are made even as they are character.
The protagonist of the story is Futaba Yoshioka: because of the sentence "I hate all males" she pronounced, a misunderstanding was created with the only boy she liked, or Kou Tanaka. The two, among other things, could no longer clarify why Tanaka moved a few days later without leaving news.Now Futaba is in high school and has changed considerably: she has taken on a somewhat rough and not very feminine attitude to avoid attracting the envy of the other girls, who considered her too cute. However, the peace that had managed to create itself will be upset by the return of Kou, who, in addition to having changed his last name, is completely different from how Futaba remembered him.\n
Wanting to go and look for the hair of the egg, the premises described above may seem a little forced, as if the author had been puzzled to look for an original incipit and to entice the public to choose its product. However, the first episode of "Ao Haru Ride" turns out to be not bad, thanks to a very sweet flashback and an equally sweet encounter.\n
The real problem, however, lies in the development of the subsequent installments. As usual, the anime in question is chock-full of all the clichés and stereotypical situations typical of shoujo: the grumpy guy who shows his tender side only with the protagonist, the study session among friends, the friend who falls in love with the same boy as the protagonist, the girl infatuated by the professor and so on. To this we must add all the various scenes that make people blush and excite, in addition to the girl in question, even the spectators (see the boy who shows up with a bare chest or who tries shamelessly without ever going to the bottom).\n
The characterization of the characters is obviously closely related to the above themes. However, even in this regard, no excellent work has been done. Let's start with Futaba: all the good things I talked about earlier were partly ruined by the usual tendencies typical of the shoujo's protagonists: for example, she follows her lover like a stalker or goes into raptures for every aspect of her, from the “form of the pretty head ”(please?) to the smell of the shampoo mixed with the smell of sweat. If with Futaba there is, therefore, a relationship of love / hate, the same is true of Kou. Certainly one cannot remain indifferent to the motivations behind his change, and that unlike the girl do not derive from a voluntary choice. However, the boy with the "door of the heart" that must be broken through to kicking if he wants to open it, is completely closed and grumpy. Because, as mentioned above, sometimes it proves, even indirectly, to be sensitive and generous. This behavior is quite unnatural and planned to ingratiate the viewers (besides being obviously predictable and typical of this stereotype).\n
The two protagonists are the only ones to talk about: except for Yuuri, who is still a not so brilliant character, Murao and Kominato remain somewhat anonymous until the last episode. Another aspect that I did not appreciate is how the group was formed: the friendship between the five boys, which is so much bandied about inside the anime, seems to be born out of nothing. It follows that the relations established between them appear very forced.\n
Let's move on to the technical side. Character design and animations are perfect in the first and in the last episode, while in the remaining ones not a little waver. On the other hand, the backgrounds are always excellent: in particular, I really liked the watercolor colors used in the flashbacks. The OSTs are quite catchy, as are the opening and ending: the first is fresh and urgent, the second is slow and melancholic. Bella also the insert song "I will" proposed several times.\n
I found Ao Haru Ride a beautiful delicate and sweet soul like the breath of a summer breeze. Ideal when you have a heart full of love and good feelings. The opening is nice and catchy, the voice is sweet and the music really remains in the heart. In conclusion, 13 episodes are few for an anime that, developed like the manga, could have done better.

The beginning premise is reminiscent of other romance anime, but what makes this stand out is the unique story-- or twist rather. The main characters are well fleshed out, and the problems they come across in their journey are unique, as far as popular romance anime is concerned. I was very intrigued, agitated, and frustrated at Yashioka's best friend as her role was different to what I've previously seen.
Overall, I enjoyed this show. The art is simply beautiful, and every time Yashioka appeared as the main subject matter onscreen I kept thinking "wow, she is beautiful." I also enjoyed the small artistic changes they madeto her character as the series proceeded.


The only thing I can comment on is that some characters are not fleshed out, but I think that is a result of insufficient seasons, and the show most likely is there to draw a manga audience.


10/10 would recommend.

I went into this expecting a cute fluffy romance. I got heartbreak instead. It was worth it.
Story 9/10: I actually found the premise interesting from the very beginning even if it's not the most original, however as it goes on, its strength doesn't lie in the progression of the plot, but in the development of the characters. 
Art 10/10: The very first thing that pulled me in was the use of watercolors in the flashbacks, I was really sad when it switched to the present and they didn't use that anymore, but other than that I have no complaints. I'm very fond of the characterdesigns and the brightness of the art really adds to the overall atmosphere.


Sound 9/10: The voice acting is solid, though I couldn't really name any outstanding performances apart from the main characters, but the ost is beautiful. It's so sweet and it fits the show so well and it is used exactly as it should be in every single scene. I've been listening to it since I finished the show and I don't plan on stopping any time soon.


Character 8/10: I don't think the characters in this can be fully appreciated without reading the manga, but the way they're presented here is still a pretty good introduction to them, especially to the main characters, though the show does a very good job with some of the side characters as well. I really love both Yoshioka and Kou's character arcs, as they both grow noticeably through the show, but of course my favourite thing is the dynamic between them. Though they do tend to not communicate as much as they should, they work very well together in any situation, and it genuinely feels like a natural progression of their relationship, not just something that happens for the sake of the plot. 


Enjoyment 7/10: There were times when I was tearing my hair out in frustration, and the ending is spectacularly unsatisfying, but I did enjoy watching it.


Overall 8/10: This is a very good romance anime, though definitely not one that I'd recommend to everyone thanks to the miscommunication, the sheer amount of internal dialogue, and the 'read the manga' ending.

Ao Haru Ride--or Blue Spring Ride was an anime that slowed down the pace for me, it made me think about my friendships, my hardships, my memories, my family and in certain cases my childhood (I'm only 15-hahahhaha). Plus I was watching fantasy, unrealistic, action type anime, and that's all I had been watching at the time. So I'm thankful that I watched this. 
Story 7/10 (Well let's just dive right into it~)
The story follows Yoshioka Futaba, Mabuchi Kou, Makita Yuuri, Murao Shuuko and Aya Kominato. All high school students, who all coincidentally have weird, teenage problems. We will discover and watch what these problemsare through not the screen, but through life itself. (Ha!)


The story felt oddly relatable to me, I'm not saying that I can personally relate to the things that happen in this, because that's too personal, and I don't want you to know that - but the story does a good job at enticing you (or at least me) into the anime. I think the reminiscing, the act of nostalgia in this anime is what makes up a good majority of the story, I mean think about it (or don't), us as humans, learn, grow, re-live and create memories from past experiences, annnnd this is exactly what Ao Haru Ride does. (spoiler) For example Futaba, gets all jittery when she sees Tanaka-kuns face after how long. She thinks back to the middle school days, where she believed she loved him. And that in turn gets her hopes up and excited!

Isn't that exactly how we as humans are? Now you can argue that this anime was created by humans, and that of course it's like this, all anime is like this... psshhhhh your dumb SunZun. But it's to reflect off of how naive we are! Just because we had a good time in the past together doesn't mean things are the same now, "you don't know me now... I'm sorry you idiot." (A quote from my childhood friend from the 1st grade...) The story just gets me thinking like this and I can't help it.


The story itself, I just felt it was lacking in something extra spicy, I'm not saying that adding another character (cough-cough) like another Mahle love interest into it would be the best option, but Futaba is just wayyyy to head over heals for Kou. And yet, that's what I find so appealing, a true Shoujo, I liked how she was trying so hard to get to know Kou better, and not just him, but everyone. I guess you could say that's how everyone is. It's just, there really isn't any major conflict except for their feelings, which is pretty basic if you ask me. But I couldn't wish for more (hahaha, JK ofc I could). Sure the simple everyday hardships they go through is normal in terms of real life, but it's how they deal with the situations that warm my heart, and magically have something fly into my eye. It's just the love triangle kills me, ( #ThatMomentWhenYouKnowThereIsAMasterRace ) not because I feel bad for one of the girls, but just because that third lover is so un-asked for. 


Overall the plot isn't complex at all, the story is simply here to comfort and settle in the characters - and was made only to define the characters. As I felt that, in this anime the story took it in day by day, you didn't know what was going to happen, only hints and tidbits of clues and foreshadow showed up. That is refreshing, being able to just go at life day by day...


Art 7/10 7.5/10


Depending on what types of art styles you are used to, this one might be new to you, as in these types of faces aren't usually generic. Personally I loved how these characters looked, at first I was a little put off, but I got use to it. The simple background was just there and I wasn't too impressed by it. Nonetheless a nice palette was used, and I think that complimented the characters and the mood of the show a lot. Overall not too bad. Oh and I liked the Opening and closing art.


Sound 8 / 10


The sound was actually pretty good. I think this show is purely based on its characters, so of course the other qualities it brings like sound will compliment what it is based on. The sound complimented the show itself as well as the story very, very, very well. The sound track just fit every mood the show had to offer, and made it even better. As for the opening and endings, I sort of liked the opening, quite a bit. And as for the endings, I sort of liked those too, their just not the most memorable. 


Character 7/10 (7.5/10)


Like I stated before, the show is heavily dependent, if not solely dependent on its main cast of characters. Which I usually don't mind in most cases, this one in particular. Characters had their ups and downs. 


The girl, Yoshioka Futaba, is a changed woman, from the cutesy rooster magnet, to the girl who stuffs herself with no shame (wait is that a problem??!??!??), meets Kou again after a few years. Kou, you can tell has gone through a lot in just those few years, from being called "Tanaka-Kun!" to "Mabuchi-kun." You can obviously tell at least a divorce had happened, not even that but his whole demeanor changed. Then, right after something that made me think about my friends happens Futaba meets, Makita Yuuri, the reincarnation of Futaba from middleschool, almost. Finally they go on to meet the other 2 which I don't really care for, Murao Shuuko and Aya Kominato.


The supporting characters are sort of just there to help make the main characters grow, which in my opinion is better than having the supporting there to just be there, but I think that the supporting characters actually had a big role in this show.


I don't know how to feel about these characters, I don't know if I should like them or not. I mean they are like able, but annoying. It's like all they have is each other and that's a bit odd, I know that you should be living for the moment with the people you care for, but the characters fail at creating a natural foundation of genuine happiness. In other words, I don't know what the characters are thinking, and I still won't know how they will act if something that offends them goes off. 

All in all these characters aren't bland, because they are good at expressing how they feel, but as a downside a majority of the time I found them to be quite predictable. And they don't really resemble anime characters (I mean they do), but more of human characters put into an anime world. 


Overall Enjoyment 10/10


I enjoyed pretty much all of this, because what can I say, I'm an easy romantic who's into love and high school students. No, but seriously, I liked the nostalgia it created, and the way it presented the "let's create memories together" part. I mean there really isn't much to say, I just really enjoyed the characters and the music.


Overall 7/10 - 7.5/10

Now, overall the story of Ao Haru Ride is pretty simple and basic. It's a down to earth story, put into the world of anime, so things aren't completely clear in the end, but the things that aren't too clear are far overshadowed by the mellow dramatic, slice of life, feel good parts. The simple aspect of livin ye lyfe to the fullest at dat darn moment, is fulfilled.

Also, I won't fail to mention that I did think the characters were a bit too soft. I had a few moments where I was like, "wow, toughen up... be like that bread lady my gawd." 

I felt that this anime was very shallow in the feelings department.


Okay honestly I don't know how to feel about this one in the end, because the ending was kind of satisfying, but mehhhhhhhhhhhhhh. Watch this if you're into mellow dramatic, touchy feely anime that has a lot of nostalgia in it.

I've put off watching Ao Haru Ride for a while. I was curious about it but it didn't really stood out from my anime line up. So, needless to say I watched it with low expectations. 
It's a shoujo, slice of life  romance about a girl who met her first love again after three years. Only, the boy she met was way different from the boy she knew three years ago. 
Well, like I mentioned before, I had low expectations for the anime because once you've noticed the shoujo romance formula, almost every other shoujo romance would start to look the same. 
Admittedly, AoHaru Ride did have that formula ( isolated herione + cool hero + new found real friends + angst + romance + school life e.g. Sukitte Ii Na Yo/ Kimi ni Todoke). Ang even though it did, I was still able to enjoy the show. 


It didn't make me feel like I was swallowing sickly sweet syrup like other romance anime did (Wow. Good job on the metaphor). In a sense, it gave me a pleasant feeling. Like, seeing my crush for the first time (Whoa! another metaphor. I'm on a roll!) But seriously, I love how the romance between Futaba and Kou is not cringey. It's wholesome and youthful, it's the "first love" kind of feeling. Ahhhh~ it gave me so many dokis.


The story was heart warming and tragic but also very relatable. It gives the viewers a lesson on changing for the better, starting over and the value of friendship (of course).


The characters are well written, but I just can't bring myself to like Kominato and Makita. However, that's a matter of preference. 


Aside from Futaba and Kou, I was also compelled by Shuuko and Tanaka-sensei's characters and their relationship. These two pairs are my otp. 


Finally, let me just say that I loved the last episode like ho-lee-sheet. Kou-kun give me a hug!


Now if you'll excuse me, it's 7:30 am and I'm going to bed. I pulled an all nighter for this anime. And the first thing I'll do when I wake up is look for and read the manga.

A história gira em torno da descoberta do amor entre os dois personagens principais, ela funciona bem para uma história de drama e romance ( possui algumas cenas muito bem feita por sinal), mas também não traz grandes novidades para esse tipo de história. Ao Haru Ride does something that most shoujo anime adaptations fail to do, and that is allowing itself to be honest and mature, denying superficiality in the way it handles its core themes. It does so with grace and precision, allowing the viewer to observe and understand the reasons for a character acting a certain way and then letting them reflect upon it. This provides it with significant emotional horsepower that propels the characters and the plot forward in an incredibly satisfying fashion. As a whole, this isn't so much a love story as it is a story about grief, friendship, and allowing oneself togrow as a person by acknowledging and accepting your past, no matter how dark it may be; not every relationship is about attraction and frivolous personality traits, some are built on hardship and the strength required to overcome it. Ao Haru Ride exemplifies this in a way most shoujo do not, while still undeniably remaining a "shoujo" anime.


This development is primarily seen in the male protagonist Mabuchi Kou, a mysterious soft-spoken boy who moved away from his middle school due to unknown reasons. Now in high school, the main female protagonist Yoshioka Futaba, whom once liked Kou, meets him again and attempts to find out what caused him to become almost the antithesis to his former self in his personality and affinity to those around him. That's the main plot in a nutshell, and while yes, there is romance involved, it's not the anime's primary focus, particularly as by the end that story thread is left inconclusive. It is primarily focused on Kou's past and how he is a very damaged person incapable of opening up, and how he grows to become someone who can do so fearlessly through the help of Futaba. While this is the case, the anime is shown from her perspective and how she also deals with anxiety and doubt, particularly struggling to find friends she can truly bond with who understand her insecurities. This becomes a major theme in the show, particularly in the beginning, and interweaves with the show's main focus in a very satisfyingly elegant way. These two protagonists have brilliant chemistry and you can't help but root for them from the very beginning of the first episode. While Ao Haru Ride excels in what it wants to say and get across, it also has a very attractive but conventional shoujo artstyle and coloring along with a very good soundtrack that places similar musical motifs throughout effectively. 


I find that the anime's main weakness is in that of the supporting cast. In fact, that name suits these relatively one-dimensional characters all-too-well; they are there only to support the main characters and not much else. While there are exceptions, most of them go through little character development over the course of the show and only appear when it is convenient for the plot. While not a large negative and pretty much a mainstay of most if not all anime and other general media, it can get distracting at times. Again, the way Ao Haru Ride handles them is nowhere near as bad as other anime, so I didn't find it to be something that brought it down as a whole. I would also find fault in the general creativity of the anime. If I had to describe it in one way, I'd say that Ao Haru Ride is the quintessential shoujo anime because it's a very generic depiction of what shoujo "should be" but done in an outstanding way. While other shoujo anime/manga like Orange have creative aspects to them, Ao Haru Ride doesn't and thus may deter certain viewers for being exactly "too generic".


I truly respect Ao Haru Ride, both the adaptation and the source material, for being very honest and mature work considering the genre it's placed under. It deals with some heavy topics such as depression, social anxiety, and how grief can make someone change themselves in a self-destructive way. However, it directly combats these darker themes with lighter ones such as forgiveness and acceptance, making it a perfect and rewarding blend of uplifting and serious. It can be deeply realistic and relatable at certain points to those who have experienced similar trauma to that of the characters, and that is to be commended. I can comfortably say that Ao Haru Ride is my favorite shoujo anime because of the beauty and elegance of its presentation, allowing one to feel and understand the guilt, trauma, and eventual absolution that its characters go through while providing a rewarding, respectful payoff.
