what really kills the mood is that the main characters are extremely undecisive if notweak. \n
the boy and girl confess to each other in the first 15 minutes of the anime, and show feelings to each other all the way down to 12 episodes, but still can't put it to solid decision.\n
another problem is, that i would have wanted this anime to have a definite ending and  not leave things on a cliffhanger(of course the mangaka wanted to make 20 more chapters and earn money), so in the end it sets off your mood.\n\n
overall this anime is a good entertainment and a must watch fr anime lovers

I was craving a good romance story after a long time without them, and seeing how many people praised Ao Haru Ride, I decided to give it a go. I liked the premise and the characters seemed like they were going to be great people for whom I could feel for. Sadly, I got absolutely nothing.
Story:
The story of Ao Haru Ride is pretty simple and straightforward. Two people, Futaba Yoshioka and Kou Mabuchi, who used to be in love with each other meet up again after three years. The girl notices the boy has changed and tries to conclude whether or not she still hasfeelings for him.

There is nothing about this premise that makes me roll my eyes as long as it is done correctly, but this was not the case here. I wasn't expecting a masterpiece when I started this, I wasn't expecting an anime that will stick with me for days. I was simply expecting a sweet story about a boy and a girl finding their way back to each other. 

I did not get that. In fact, I didn't really get anything. They are not finding their way back to each other, they are not even trying. It has mostly been a story about the Futaba crying how Kou has changed, and Kou telling Futaba how much she has changed. It was fine the first two times they mentioned it, but it was severely overused.

I guess someone must have realized this alone will not make for a good story, so they decided to push a friendship group subplot. Again, it's something I have no problems with, but I have a lot of problems with this specific friendship group. I don't understand why they are friends other than for the simple reason to have friends. They don't seem to have any shared interests, they don't seem to enjoy each other's company that much. They simply exist in the same place and time. 

This anime is, however, supposed to be character driven, so I didn't let the story alone determine my score, even though the story was almost non existent, but I still gave it a 6/10.


Art:

Production I.G. has once again done a really good job with animation. The style is sweet, enhanced with a color palette that matches a slice of life anime. The pastel-like colors while showing flashbacks were a nice touch as well. I did feel like the chibi style was a bit overused, but it didn't bother me too much. I haven't noticed any drops in quality over the course of the show, which is why I gave the art an 8/10.


Sound:

Opening and Ending songs were fine. Nothing special, nothing that will stick with me, but they were good songs for this particular anime. As for the rest of the soundtrack throughout the show, I am very conflicted as to what exactly to say. 

Some songs were such a good hit in a specific moment, enhancing the emotion trying to be shown. If it weren't for them, there would be absolutely no moment of this show that made me feel, but like I said, they really did a great job at choosing at which point to start playing which song. Of course, this is a double-edged sword, as some songs seemed were put in moments that were already overly dramatic, and the songs just enhanced all of that and it felt like I was left with so much melodrama that was completely unnecessary. 

When it comes to voice acting, I had no problems with it. It wasn't remarkable, but it was done well, which is why my final grade for the sound is 5/10.


Character:

When you go into a character driven story, you expect the characters to be intriguing and entertaining. It makes me sad to say that this was definitely not the case here. 

Let's start with Futaba, our female lead. Futaba is first shown as this cute, little girl whose problem is the fact that she is too cute. She is so cute, that every girl in her middle school got angry at her and stopped talking to her. She decided she wanted to make friends in high school, so she changed into a girl who doesn't comb her hair and eats a lot. A really huge change, I know.

Seeing how she is the main character of this show, you'd expect her to have a big role, but I just didn't get that impression. She was bland and went through minimal development. From time to time, it seemed as if the only point of having her in the show was to develop Kou, which isn't a bad thing in itself, but it becomes really bad since she is supposed to be a main character. 


Moving on to Kou, who also managed to make me so mad. I liked him at the beginning. I knew from the get-go that his cold demeanor was just a mask and I was really looking forward to finding out why exactly that was the case. But sadly, I barely got anything. Turns out, he really is just a moody, cold, quiet, 'caring only brings suffering' type of a person. That is, he is that way right until the end, when he suddenly changes because Futaba made him see how much good there is in the world. 


And that brings me to another part of the anime which I just don't understand. I picked this up because it says romance and because I liked the premise, but I got nothing when it comes to the relationship. It had no development, it wasn't believable, there simply wasn't anything there. If this anime didn't have a romance tag, I would have no problems with this, but I was expecting a lot more in regards to this. 


I'll just briefly mention the 4 other characters who were kind of relevant to the story, but also not really. 

We have Yuuri who is a cute girl who every other girls hates because of it. Sounds familiar? Yes, I know. 

Murao is a cold girl who has a crush on a teacher and doesn't like hanging out with people from her class. Until she becomes a part of the group we follow and then suddenly starts to like hanging out just like that, completely out of the blue and incredibly out of character.

I don't even know what the point of Kominato is. He is a part of the friend group, but it seemed like he was there simply so they could have another boy in there.

And finally, we have Tanaka, Kou's older brother and the only character from this anime which I actually liked. There wasn't even anything that special about him, but compared to everyone else, he seemed like a person who had a reason to be in this story. 


Enjoyment:

I enjoyed the first two or three episodes. I really did, and I was looking forward to watching everything and finding out more about the characters and seeing how their story will end. But with time, my enjoyment just completely went away. There was nothing going on that made me interested and I got so bored, which is saying a lot considering how short this anime is. 


Overall:

Even though I came into this with very little expectations despite so many good reviews, I still got nothing. I got no romance, I went into a character driven story and was given completely bland characters and a bunch of unnecessary characters. The sound and animation were ultimately the only thing that saved this anime, so it gets a 4/10 from me.

To be fair, I may be a little biased because I was in the mood to see a cute shoujo anime. What I liked about this was that the interactions between the two characters are much more natural than in most anime of the sort. Yes, she blushes and cries, he knocks her on the head, calling her "baka", but the flow feels way more normal than your usual anime and they don't "combust" if they touch hands :P
Story - 8 Because yes, it has its tropes and it is pretty typical, but it has its depth and, as I said, a good overall flowto it. 


Art - 9 I really liked how the characters were drawn, very cute expressions and the splashes of watercolors in the memory scenes were a very nice touch!  


Sound 9 - The intro is really catchy and stays with you and the sountrack complemented the story and highlighted the major points. Also, their voices were very nice and some of her replies when upset/flustered/embarrassed were extremely cute. Also, his laugh...:) 


Character 8 - Only 8 because not all characters had the required depth, there were a few tropes and stereotypes, but overall they were extremely likable 


Enjoyment 10 - Very cute and fun, with a tinge of darkness and sorrow and well depicted adolescent confusion that leaves room for both errors and drama, but also growth and sweetness  :) 


Overall 9 - Because it felt cut short and I wanted more...it actually leaves room for more (the following OVA brings a bit more but still not enough). Then again, it is a high mark because, since the manga was ongoing and it only had 12 episodes, it managed to leave its mark.


For those who compare it to Kimi ni Todoke (and especially those who find it to be less) I have to say i can't find the resemblance, except, maybe, the fact they were both from the same period, treating the high school romance theme like many, many others. Also, Kimi ni todoke had a greater hype built around it, much more money invested in it and more episodes which made it possible for the public to enjoy more content and develop story end characters further. I, for one was not overly impressed by that one and prefer Ao Haru Ride.

First love is something that you won't forget easily...or is it? and how much a person able to change in just a few years. That's what Ao Haru Ride's main plot surrounds itself in. The story starts with our main character, Futaba Yoshioka, falls in love with a boy named Kou Tanaka, they planned to go on a date together one spring night but Kou never showed up on the night of their date, leaving Futaba disappointed. Kou transferred school during the spring season and they never meet again, not until few years later that Futaba meets up with Kou again in their high school.But this Kou is completely a different Kou that she used to know, leaving her wondering what makes Kou such a different person than the one that she loved. The story in this anime is "Cute" from my perspective, it doesn't have a big twist or a shocking moment, it's just a generic love story with some cuties moments. (But it's still better than some romcom anime). The art in this anime is gorgeous and the voice actors done a every excellent job to express the characters' emotions. The soundtracks for this anime is amazing, I immediately went to download the whole soundtracks after i finished the first episode. The characters are likable especially Futaba and Kou, they are very well developed in my opinion. Overall, I really like this anime, it's an enjoyable anime. 8/10

This is your typical shoujo anime so there's nothing particularly unique about the story line. However, I must say there were many ridiculous WTF how did that just happen, cheesy, and overly dramatic moments in this series, especially in the beginning. I was actually very tempted to drop the anime after 3 episodes but if you bear with the terrible opening episodes you'll come to enjoy the rest of the series. I didn't really like the MC's Futaba Yohioka or Kou Tanaka/Mabuchi but I liked their budding chemistry and enjoyed their subtle romantic moments. Oh but I thought the third wheel Makita Yuri was EXTREMELYANNOYING. I hated how she acts cute and pretends to be innocent while lusting after Kou. She really just needs to get over herself and accept the fact that someone else deserves her crush better than her. Also, I hated Kou's lethargic voice because I thought it was overdone, but then later discovered that the seiyuu for Kou also voiced Kenma from Haikyuu! which changed my disposition. I freakin love Haikyuu so the fact that Kou's seiyuu also voiced a character from my favorite anime made Kou's boring voice more bearable to listen to~ :D hehe. ... But overall this was a charming shoujo anime. If you're looking to watch a short anime filled with sweet moments, then I recommend checking out Ao Haru Ride.

Ao Haru Ride is your standard shoujo romance, nonetheless it’s still entertaining and a show I would heartily recommend if you’re a fan of the genre. The show starts out strong- a lot of progress is made in the first few episodes, but it wastes its head start by slightly lagging towards the middle and end. There are some sweet heart-throbbing moments peppered here and there. 
I am obsessed with Kou. He is a hot guy with a sexy, husky voice. Kudos to his seiyuu! Seriously, I wish all shoujo guys sounded like him. Kou is also sort of a tsundere and can occasionally actlike a jerk. 


Futaba, the female lead, is persistent when it comes to trying to get Kou to open up. I don’t like her character design as much as Kou’s design; her eyes are super round and a bit too far apart. But that’s just me. 


The side characters aren’t anything to write home about. I honestly didn’t care about them at all (though they do get a bit more development in the manga).  


The OP is really cute and catchy.

This anime is full of heart-stopping romantic moments, I really enjoyed it. I can't quite believe it's not quite over that 8 rating yet, although it is very close. I love that the female lead has a specific, cute fetish about the MC, I really related to that. She also has a great character - funny, sweet, conflicted. The female relationships are also very relatable - it was heartening to see truly good hearts find each other and overcome many of the aspects of teenage life that would normally pull friendships apart. Overall, very relatable, really enjoyable, very funny in parts too!

Ao Haru Ride follows Futaba and Kou two kids who meet in middle school and fall in love. A heart aching love story of two kids who fall in love and loose each other, but later on meet again for a second chance. You follow these characters in high school as they try to make friends and get through the everyday struggles of high school. Futaba desperately tries to make Kou go back to the way he was because now he isn't the same small soft middle school kid she once knew. But yet a mysteriously non caring high school boy, she remembers the boyshe loved in middle school and knows he is still the same loving boy. So you watch her struggle to make him open up and be a happy boy like he was in the past and win his heart over again one more time... I personally loved this series I held it off for some reason but so glad I watched this on my top rated shows of all time for sure just fell in love with this series with the beautiful visuals, amazing characters, and heart warming story of two lovers. \n

I'm very, very annoyed with Ao Haru Ride at the moment. I write this whilst hitting my head against a proverbial brick wall, wondering why I wasted four hours of my PRECIOUS life watching such a limp anime when so many of my friends told me to avoid it. I just had to be a rebel, didn't I?
I've got nothing against the shoujo demographic, romance or slice of life - I actually really enjoy it when its done well. Unfortunately, this was absolutely not the case with Ao Haru Ride. It spent 9-10 episodes doing nothing but play endless feeling ping-pong. Some semblance of aplot didn't actually kick in until episode 11, but by then it was too late because that was the penultimate episode of the anime. The story was so limp that the cheese dangling in front a mouse plot device used at the end of episode 12 did not excite me an ounce, because by the time the thing was finished I was barely paying attention.


I know this is a slice-of-life anime thus it isn't really meant to have an overarching plot because it's more about the characters, than the story. But when an anime has characters as flat, shallow and soulless as the ones in AHR the anime has a big problem. 


There was hardly any character development from any of the characters outside of the main pair. The supporting cast were frankly irrelevant and a waste of screen time. I didn't know any of their names and you could have swapped others in their place and I probably wouldn't have noticed.


Kou was the only one who had significant character development and it wasn't anything exciting at all. You see, despite what some will say about him, Kou is nothing but a 16 year-old arsehole with angst issues. His character trajectory is supposed to make us feel like he's something else, but he doesn't even have a trajectory that makes him redeemable. Everyone else around him is doing all the hard work whilst he's just stringing them along and confusing them emotionally - this is especially the case with Futaba. 


I know the difficult time he went through affected his personalit, but it isn't any justification for how he treated people. What he did was morally reprehensible: he always played push-and-pull games with people, without giving a second thought towards their feelings. I've seen people do that in real life and TRUST ME when I say that it doesn't end well. Nobody will put up with that shit for a long time - no matter how much they care about you - because people like Kou are highly taxing on one's emotional stability.


I'm annoyed with Futaba for loving Kou, but, otherwise, I actually like her. I think she's got some horrible taste in friends and men, but she's honest and she's got guts. I'm glad that she finally realised it's okay to be yourself, and be hated for it, instead of being loved for who you aren't. Her character development was incredibly short though, and she stagnated after the fourth episode. Nevertheless, she was the gem in the dust and I saw aspects of myself in her at times.


Makita Yuuri is the only supporting character I'm going to talk about because, for about 30 seconds, she was a plot pusher. The other lot are so irrelevant I can't even remember their faces (and I finished the anime just over an hour ago). I have no problems with cute characters, but Yuuri wasn't cute she was just plain sly. She says it herself, at the very beginning, that she only acts cute because she wants male attention and appreciation. Not only is that incredibly sly, but it sends out an absolutely awful message to young girls (and boys). I also don't get why Yuuri and Futaba are such "precious" friends - asides from being hated by girls for being cute, what do you they really have in common? Their relationship was so superficial. I also didn't like how Yuuri could be so foxy and pragmatic when it came to Kou, but could get away with it because she acted like a three year old. 


The art and music in AHR might have been really pretty, but that doesn't detract away from the anime's clear and undeniable flaws that obviously impact on one's enjoyment factor. You can't save an anime from the poorly construed characters that are supposed to hold the show together.

The story was a basic story line, with it's own spin on it and a lot of blush-worthy moments and heart-racing ones. The characters are all likable. The art was beautiful, I love the watercolor effect the artist used on the flash backs. It was very well done and the development of the characters got me attached. It kind of made me think of My Little Monster but the roles were reversed. I was kind of sad at the ending because I want to see more and know how it does end it because it leaves it open and I don't like it, haha. ButI still rate it high because the rest of the anime was top-notch. Decent characters and funny lines along with dramatic scenes and a girl like a storm.

This show is going to be weird for me to write a review for, i stumbled across it on my recommended list while wandering aimlessly on Hulu.  
Two middle school students. A male and a female. The male asks out said female.  She would have accepted but for some reason indirectly rejects him while trying to deny the crush she has for said boy.  He goes away and then they are reunited as high school students.  So she tries everything in her power to try to get them to start going out as they should have in high school but onething leads to another and he says he doesnt have those feelings for her anymore.  So she tries to make him fall in love with her and that's basically the entire story.  


Now i don't know too much about the female's mindset but granted that the story was told from the perspective of the female protagonist Yoshioka Futaba. there is a lot for me to ponder about this show.  Personally because i don't understand the whole thing about love and relationships and crap.  (pardon my french)  


Ultimately i wanted to put a boot in her face and watch her bleed out.  But for someone who knows how this stuff works, i would both recommend you watch it, and then explain to me how her mind is working.  That would be appreciated.

This is one of my first anime I've watched, and it is so fabulous. *o* If you want some romance, nice art, music and feels, this is the anime for you~! This is the first anime that made me actually bother to read continue the story by reading the manga. That definitely tells you something ;)
Story: Really liked it, it's pretty interesting.
Art: Presentation is beautiful and really nice. Kou is so handsome. :3
Sound: Outstanding. The music totally matches the moods, and is really catchy. The OST 'I Will' is so good~ and you don't get sick of it, even though it's used a lot. Eventhough it's been ages since I've first watched Ao Haru Ride, I still remember the tune of this song. The songs are brilliant, and the voice-acting matches well.


Character: It is refreshing to see the characters gradually develop, like how Futaba started changing her views, thanks to Kou.


Enjoyment: Quite enjoyed it, some parts were a bit overused, but overall I quite enjoyed watching Ao Haru Ride.


Overall: Just my opinion, but this is a great romance shoujo anime to watch! I especially enjoyed the sounds. The plot was touching, and this anime makes you have feels.

Ao Haru Ride is one of the few romance animes that tug at my heart strings, maybe because the story is so tragic...the characters are so complex yet so beautiful at the same time... or I'm just a sucker for tragic romance with happy endings. 
Ao Haru Ride does not gloss over a person's feelings nor try to simplify a relationship. And indeed people can be so much more complex than you think. There are many romantic scenes that made me go "doki doki" :) and I rooted for the couple from start to end, yet I felt for the secondary characters so much! AfterI completed the anime, I couldn't get all those feelings out of me for a long time that I kept listening to its theme song "I Will". 


Ao Haru Ride's artwork is splendid, the characters are likeable, and there are many heartbreaking scenes that made me teared and my heart pounded.


It is one of the few animes that lingers in my heart long after it ended.

I know the opinions differ but I still think this is a great anime coming out of my re-watch. In it's 12 episodes it manage to make me care for it's characters, cry for it's characters and it also makes my heart race. It had a very small amount of problems for me, one of them being that it's too short, which is, of course not something that you can call criticism, just greediness on my part.
NO SPOILERS AHEAD
Now, I know it's not really a very original story. It shows things that you find in a loooot of shoujo anime, but to me it showsexactly those things that I like about shoujo anime compared to other kinds of fiction. It is character driven, sweet and thinks it's choices and moralities through. It's not just a big ball of hormones like a lot of American entertainment is. 

Personally I started watching this in an attempt to fill the void that kimi ni todoke left. I found another sweet story in this anime. I love it's philosophy, and even though I can see the cliche's, they don't bother me that much. It shows me things that I wish I'd have the power to do: drawing people out and drawing people in, with trying, caring and a little guts.


CHARACTERS

So we have a good female MC, Futuba I like how she feels like a teenager, caving into the temptation and pretending to be who her friends think she is. I also like that she has courage. She has some great character development and is overall fun to watch while she balances her behavior between what her habits tell her to do versus what she wants to do. The male MC is lovable, he pretends not to care but obviously does, well, you know the type, imagine that stereotypical male MC with a great dry voice actor, actual backstory and then ten times better and you have our Kou. There are some other characters that don't get a lot of development but what do you want in 12 episodes?


PHILOSOPHY

Now I realize this is shoujo anime and that philosophy is barely relevant, but to me it matters a great deal if a story has something to teach me or something for me to wonder about. In the anime we see a couple of flashbacks to the Kou and Futaba in middle school, when they started to like each other. In those flashbacks they are both very different from the way they are when we get to know them. This is something I find very interesting personally, whether the fact that people change matters to the ones who really love them. Isn't unconditional love very illogical? If characteristics don't matter anymore what is it that we love? When you love someone who's changed, does that mean that you love them as someone new entirely? Or is there something in people that is always there, no matter how much they change? Or does loving them mean that you're just waiting for the person they were to come out again? Ao Haru Ride doesn't give you any answers but it does have a nice story about two characters who experience real change but either still love each other and/or learn to love each other the way they are now.


ART AND SOUND 

The art is really great, it's just really pretty. It has nice body proportions, backgrounds, there are no animation issues that sprung out at me, it also has fantastic facial expressions. 

I really love the music, too, I like the theme song and the song they end with, but it also has a beautiful soundtrack that is alternated with the amazing song "I will". The voice actors were also very good. 


So I think you get that I liked it a lot. Don't watch this if you're looking for something different and original. But if you're looking for a short, sweet and well-executed love story you should watch this :) It won't take long so enjoy it while it lasts. Oh and watch the extra "unwritten" episodes, it might give you a little more closure.

I just rewatched the entire show in a matter of two days. I did so because someone asked me if I had seen it and wanted to know my opinion. I couldn't remember the story or if I liked it, so I decided to watch it again. That right there is a red flag, because I normally remember most anime I watch. The pace of this anime is kind of slow, even for the slice of life genre. The beginning is a bit confusing because you're not quite sure if the two main characters know each other, but that's fine, we get the gist ofthis story arc by episode three.


The art is dreamy and sort of washed out in watercolors, very easy on the eyes.


The characters are developed well enough, but kind of one dimensional. Kou is interesting, though he made me mad many times.  Futaba sort of just took his emotional beatings without worry of her own self. If she were a real person/friend, I would tell her to leave him for being so mean to her. 


Someone mentioned not liking the voice of the female lead... My advice is to stop watching it in dub! Seriously.


Overall I thought it was pretty good, not really great though. I Enjoyed this more as a story of friendship, not so much a romance, mainly because it's a bit disappointing as a romance.

Well, wasn't this a great anime!? I feel like it ended a bit too abruptly, with a lot left to offer from the plot, and no closure was given (if you haven't read the manga). That said, every moment of this was beautiful, the romance scenes were on point, no complaints whatsoever, I REGRET NOTHING! Really good (cuuute) OST, melts my heart every time. This whole anime melted my heart.
Overall [10/10] - All of the above, great character development, really shows Kou embracing his feelings and becoming more open, and oh man the romantic scenes were so good... Really brilliant anime, will never forget it,and will probably re-watch! Also, to anyone who hasn't, read the manga! You're missing out (since it looks like there may not be a season 2, even though I hate to say it)!

This summer I have a lot of free time and still this anime took me a a little bit longer to finish.  It's rather sad because after the first episode I thought it was going to be amazing and couldn't wait to see what else this anime had in store.  But as more characters were introduced and time went on, the anime seemed to move so slow, and unfortunately became boring.  The ending, while I won't give anything away, just didn't at all feel like a proper ending.  While there are no cliffhangers or gripping questions and no one is onthe edge of their seat, the audience is left hungry as if all twelve episodes were all for naught.\n\n
Thankfully, there exists a side story to this anime.  The OVA episode called "Page 13" of this anime contains the true ending that probably would raise this series' overall score by a whole point.  I recommend that episode more than I recommend half the episodes in the main series.

One of my first shoujo romance animes I have ever watched and I got to say it is one of the best as compared to other animes similar in genre to this. The story's pacing and character development is pretty good in my opinion. 
The art, especially the scenic views in this anime is exceptionally breathtaking that I wish I was there. The characters are well drawn as well, much identical to the manga. For the sound, it was a good listen. The OSTs used in here is very good and addictive. So, no complains here as well.
Overall, I give this a solid 10/10 andI really recommend this anime to everyone out there because it is sure to remind you of your high school life and how some events are relatable to our daily lives.\n

Ao Haru Ride is in a word: A'ight
I wasn't impressed. In fact, I was a little disappointed because so many people hyped it up as a "must see Shoujo anime", but if you don't watch it you're not missing much.
I think the characters lacked personality, the story was mediocre, the bond between the leads was tissue paper thin, and the hyped "romantic" moments weren't all that romantic. 
When I finished it, I wished that I had just re-watched Kimi ni Todoke instead. 
If you are in the mood it watch something that you don't have to pay much attention to then this is the animefor you.

This anime is about a girl named Futaba Yoshioka who, has had a past with a boy named Kou Tanaka. They were both in love with each other but one day Futaba said something to someone trying to bother her. She said she hated all boys, while Kou was coming out of the classroom. Kou was supposed to meet her at a park Futaba showed up but Kou never did. Kou moved to another city due to family problems and was disconnected from Futaba and his friends. A few years later passed now Futaba is in Highschool she one day bumps into a boy thatlooked like Kou but due to family problems he changed his last name so they called him Mabuchi. Futaba was embarassed that she was "mistakened" but, she wasn't. She later finds out that was actually the boy she once loved and he has moved back into to town. She finds out by hiding under a shrine while it was raining between some walls she discovers Kou there also and that how she confirmed that was the real Kou and he has changed a lot; personality wise and looks wise. It made them both nostalgic because during 7th/8th grade when they were both in love they were hiding in the exact same place.



In this series it takes about love complications and growing a bond with each other from people who were disconnected, anti social, and alone. To being a group of good friends together later on in the series. In the anime it doesn't have a season 2 but it leaves off in the manga at chapter 15. 



The manga has lots of harem/drama and is very beautiful is you love the Ao Haru Ride series give a manga a go to finish the whole series.

Story:
Standard shojo highschool setting, don't expect anything new in that direction. The backstory and connection of the two main characters stands out. Especially the past of the male lead takes an unusual route and creates interesting character dynamics.
Art:
Good, nothing that takes you out of it. That's about it.
Sound:
The OST of this anime is surprisingly good and fits the overall theme well. Absolutly no complaints here.
Character:
The cast of characters is well mixed and the amount of character development satisfying and realistic in terms of anime. Still there are some cliché characters but this can be expected. I especially liked Kou's brother as his troubles dealing withhim and one of his studends were believable and made him relatable.\n\n
Enjoyment:\n
While the anime was pleasant to watch, the slow pase of story and character develpment meant, that in the end not much changed. Or rather that there was no time left for it to take effect. With a slightly faster pace or a couple of episodes more there could have been a satisfying ending. As for the actual ending you are left without any closure. This transforms what could have been a sweet 12 episode anime into an unfullfilling teaser for the manga, that leaves you with a hollow feeling.\n\n
TLDR:\n
With a more fullfilling ending (that still could have left room for the manga / a second season) I would have given this anime a 8/10 as a great, even though somewhat vanilla, experience. Sadly its ending drops all the momentum to the floor and leaves you rather unsatisfied considering how well it all started.
